misconceptions.name: Reads wrong number and type of inputs for the task
misconceptions.description: The program asks for three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers as required, indicating a misunderstanding of the input requirements for this problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should prompt for v0, v1, and t as doubles and use those as the inputs to my program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly five integers from the user (e.g., using nextInt in a loop or repeated calls) in order to later sum only the even ones.
symptoms: Prompt text mentions v0, v1, and t instead of five integers
Only three values are read instead of five
nextDouble is used instead of nextInt
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reusing code from an unrelated exercise about acceleration rather than implementing the specified input behavior for this question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the prompt and use nextInt to read five separate integers from the user, storing or processing each one as you go.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variable names, prompt, and use of three double inputs clearly correspond to a different problem than the one described.

evidence.note: The code reads three double values v0, v1, and t instead of five integers as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The solution processes a fixed set of three values once and does not use any loop to handle multiple inputs, which is required to process five numbers efficiently.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve the problem by reading a few values once without needing a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle five integers systematically (and to generalize to more inputs), the program should use a loop (for or while) that iterates five times, reading and processing each input inside the loop.
symptoms: No for or while loop in the program
Inputs are read by a small fixed sequence of nextDouble calls
Program cannot scale to handle an arbitrary number of values
misconceptions.root_cause: Focus on a different problem (acceleration calculation) that naturally uses a single formula instead of repeated processing of multiple numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that runs five times; in each iteration, read one integer and update any necessary computations such as the even-number sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The main method contains only straight-line code with three input reads and no looping constructs.

evidence.note: The entire program body is straight-line code; there is no for or while loop to iterate over five inputs.

misconceptions.name: No check for even numbers or accumulation of their sum
misconceptions.description: Instead of checking whether each input number is even and accumulating a sum of even numbers, the code computes an average acceleration formula (v1 - v0) / t and prints that result.
misconceptions.student_belief: The required output is the average acceleration computed from v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each of the five input integers, the program must check if the number is even using a condition like n % 2 == 0 and, if so, add it to a running sum. After processing all inputs, it should print the sum of even numbers.
symptoms: No use of the modulus operator (%)
No conditional logic related to even or odd numbers
The computed value is (v1 - v0) / t, not a sum of selected inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: Directly implementing a different textbook problem about acceleration instead of the specified even-number summation problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the acceleration formula with logic that initializes an integer sum to 0, then for each of the five inputs uses if (n % 2 == 0) sum += n; and finally prints the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The printed message and formula clearly correspond to an average acceleration task and there is no trace of even-number logic or summation.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The code calculates and prints an average acceleration instead of summing even numbers; there is no conditional check like n % 2 == 0 or an integer sum accumulator.

misconceptions.name: Solved an Entirely Different Problem
misconceptions.description: The student code calculates average acceleration based on three double inputs (v0, v1, t). This is completely unrelated to the assigned task, which was to read 5 integers and calculate the sum of the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were assigned a problem related to physics calculations (acceleration) rather than array/loop processing and conditional logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should iterate 5 times, read an integer in each iteration, check if the integer is even using the modulus operator, and accumulate the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code executes acceleration calculation logic.
Input prompts are for v0, v1, and t.
The logic (loops, conditionals) required by the problem is missing.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment prompt or substituting code from another exercise, leading to a complete failure to meet any stated requirement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read the assignment instructions. The goal is to calculate a sum using conditional logic and iteration, not a single mathematical formula.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code's output and logic are demonstrably for a different problem standard (acceleration calculation).

evidence.note: The entire program implements acceleration calculation, not the required sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Used 'double' when 'int' was required
misconceptions.description: The problem specifically required reading 5 *integers*. The student's code reads 3 floating-point numbers (`double`) using `nextDouble()`. This violates the basic type constraint of the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that numerical inputs should generally be doubles, or did not realize that `int` was required by the problem's criteria (checking for evenness, which implies integer arithmetic).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When dealing with counting, iteration, or checking for even/oddness, the `int` data type is appropriate, and `input.nextInt()` should be used.
symptoms: Variable declarations use `double`.
Input methods use `nextDouble()`.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion regarding the proper data type for input when the required operation (checking evenness) relies on integer properties.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Pay close attention to the requested data type (e.g., 'integer' vs. 'number'). Use `input.nextInt()` and declare variables as `int` for integer inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student explicitly used `double` declarations and `nextDouble()` repeatedly, directly contradicting the requirement for 'integers'.

evidence.note: The inputs are defined and read as `double`s, not `int`s as required by the problem description.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved - completely different program
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating acceleration from physics (v = v0 + at), not a program to sum even numbers. This indicates either a copy-paste error, submission of the wrong file, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving an acceleration calculation problem rather than the assigned even number sum problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones. This is a data input, loop, and conditional logic exercise, not a physics calculation.
symptoms: Code reads 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration formula instead of filtering for even numbers
Output message mentions 'average acceleration' instead of 'sum of even numbers'
No loop structure for processing 5 values
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0)
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted the wrong program entirely - likely copied from a different assignment or copied someone else's work without adapting it.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the correct problem. Use Scanner.nextInt() in a loop to read 5 integers. Use modulo operator (%) to check if each number is even before adding to a sum variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration) with no overlap to the assigned problem (even number sum). The mismatch is unambiguous.

evidence.note: This code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration, not the assigned task of reading 5 integers and summing even ones.
Output is about acceleration, not about sum of even numbers as required.

misconceptions.name: Implements average acceleration instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program computes and prints an average acceleration value based on v0, v1, and t instead of summing the even numbers among 5 user-entered integers as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that calculates the average acceleration from v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, select only the even ones, and compute and print the sum of those even numbers.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Computation uses (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing selected inputs.
Output message is 'The average acceleration is ...' rather than 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a different textbook-style problem (average acceleration) rather than the specified task (sum of even numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and rewrite main so that it reads 5 integers, checks which are even, accumulates their sum, and prints the correct message.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All variable names, prompt text, and formula correspond to an acceleration calculator problem and do not reference 5 integers or even-number summation at all.

evidence.note: Prompts for v0, v1, and t; computes (v1 - v0) / t; and prints 'The average acceleration is', which does not relate to summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for a different purpose instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers as required for summing even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should read three real-valued inputs (v0, v1, t) from the user for this problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly five integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt()), which will later be filtered for even numbers and summed.
symptoms: Uses nextDouble() three times instead of nextInt() five times.
Input prompt asks for three values (v0, v1, t) rather than five integers.
No mechanism exists to obtain five separate integer inputs from the user.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between this assignment and a different example problem that uses three double inputs for an acceleration calculation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input section to prompt for and read five integers (e.g., in a loop using nextInt()) and store or process them for even-number summation.
related_concepts: Using Scanner for integer vs. double input
Mapping problem requirements to input variables
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly reads three doubles with names tied to an acceleration problem and never uses nextInt() or any structure to read five integers.

evidence.note: Uses nextDouble() to read three values v0, v1, and t instead of reading five integers as specified.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation (Acceleration Calculation)
misconceptions.description: The student has written a program to calculate acceleration instead of the required program to find the sum of 5 even numbers. The inputs are three doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to be submitting code for a completely different and unrelated assignment (Acceleration Calculator), suggesting a fundamental error in selecting or developing the correct program for Q1: Sum of Even Numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be structured to solve the problem described in Q1: read exactly 5 integers and calculate the sum of those which are even.
symptoms: Prompts the user for 'v0, v1, and t'
Reads three double values instead of five integer values
Performs acceleration calculation (v1 - v0) / t
Prints a message about 'average acceleration'
misconceptions.root_cause: Major context switching error or submission of the wrong file. The student's code addresses a physics/mathematics problem (acceleration) that is irrelevant to the assigned CS problem (Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the current code and start fresh, focusing only on the requirements of the Sum of Even Numbers problem. Ensure you read five integers and use a loop/conditional logic for summation.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code directly implements acceleration calculation as evidenced by the class name, prompts, variable names, and calculation logic. It fails every requirement of the assigned problem.

evidence.note: Class name indicates a different program.
Input prompt is for variables related to acceleration, not 5 integers.
Performs acceleration calculation instead of sum calculation.
